text: What does a content marketing career path look like? That's the topic of my new article, and I'd love to get perspective from the knowledgeable content marketers in this chat! How did your career in content marketing start out. What types of skills did you need to advance? What are your career aspirations? CMO? Founder of your own company? Or maybe content marketing is just a way to subsidize that novel you're writing. I'd love to hear some thoughts! Thank you in advance :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I figured! Would love to talk in more detail. Maybe we could set up a call?

elements.text: I figured! Would love to talk in more detail. Maybe we could set up a call?

text:
I have covered a lot of the skills needed to get into and excel at content in this (lengthy) blog: <http://www.jillianwood.com/2019/04/22/how-to-become-b2b-tech-content-marketer/>

I came from a journalist-y, writer background in trade publishing. I don’t talk too much about future paths in the piece…but damn I hope some of us get into CMO roles someday. Messaging underpins everything you do in marketing--but you need a strong data/analysis background to get there, too--which I think is harder to come by in content roles.

<@URAV154AV> would be awesome to speak to about moving from just content to more general marketing director roles i bet :slightly_smiling_face:

attachments.title: How Do I Become A (B2B Tech) Content Marketer? | Jillian S. Wood
attachments.text: Learn about the skills and experience you need to become a content marketer for a tech or B2B company.
attachments.fallback: How Do I Become A (B2B Tech) Content Marketer? | Jillian S. Wood

text: I came to content from journalism. Happy to chat about that perspective, if that's of interest.

elements.text: I came to content from journalism. Happy to chat about that perspective, if that's of interest.

text: When I majored in marketing in the early aughts, no one had coined the term "content marketing" yet. I was a general marketing coordinator with an event focus before I created a role as an in-house editor, and then when I left that job, I learned that content marketing was all the rage!

elements.text: When I majored in marketing in the early aughts, no one had coined the term "content marketing" yet. I was a general marketing coordinator with an event focus before I created a role as an in-house editor, and then when I left that job, I learned that content marketing was all the rage!

text: I graduated with a heavy focus on creative writing and classic lit. Digital marketing was just becoming all the rage, and I feel I grew in marketing as marketing, as we know it today (SEO, analytics, content marketing, etc) grew as well. I loved writing everything and wrote everything I could and several blogs, websites, landing pages, e-books, etc. later, my creative side led me down the path of creative directorship and brand work. I'm a content marketing manager now, which is described as an "editor-in-chief" in my job description, which is pretty perfect if I stay in marketing. I'm still wondering if my ultimate goal is a CMO, and right now, I'm leaning towards "no", but I'm still exploring! Good luck on your article. :slightly_smiling_face: Happy to chat more if needed.

I'm a content marketing manager now, which is described as an "editor-in-chief" in my job description, which is pretty perfect if I stay in marketing. I'm still wondering if my ultimate goal is a CMO, and right now, I'm leaning towards "no", but I'm still exploring! Good luck on your article.
Happy to chat more if needed.

text: I don’t have time to write out my whole story right now (probably not until next week) but def happy to chat if you still need thoughts!

elements.text: I don’t have time to write out my whole story right now (probably not until next week) but def happy to chat if you still need thoughts!

text:
My career involves quite a bit of being knocked around but the short version is that I found out IBM was hiring freelance writers via Indeed. Me, studying Economics at the time to be an analyst, applied, got brought onboard.

The agency sent me a bunch of big name clients - I then realized I could make a living writing.

Leveraged those logos, to get more clients via word of mouth. Completed my B.S. - ended up freelancing, then got a job at Airbnb for a growth project, then became a Content Marketing Manager for a startup (no longer around)

Went back into consulting.

Then I got a call from a recruiter about eBay hiring a content strategist. At first I almost turned them away because the job description said it involved UX work.

Ended up going through the process... and now I'm immersed in product marketing and I'm also a community manager.

I never imagined I'd be a community manager, and in terms of product marketing, I thought I'd need an MBA to pick up what I'm learning now.

So the tl;dr to all this is that I just got into content by chance, networked a ton, and just adapted to change and took adversity in stride.

A ton has changed in the 12 years since I was just cranking out articles for IBM at a (relatively) low amount.

Feel free to DM if you would like to get more context.
